Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the father should purchase it
Situation2: A funeral prayer needs exactly one more participant to form the required quorum.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my son’s hopeful eyes fixed on me as he reminded me, “You promised, Dad. You said you’d get me the Nintendo this week.” I glanced at the bills stacked beside my coffee mug, calculating what I could stretch and what I couldn’t. Money was tight, but I’d made a promise, and I wanted to keep it. Just as I was about to reassure him, my phone buzzed. It was David from the synagogue—there was a funeral prayer, and they needed one more for the minyan. Without me, the prayer couldn’t happen. I felt the weight of my community’s expectation pressing on me, the sacred duty to honor the dead and support grieving families. My son’s face was still hopeful, unaware of the call’s gravity. I felt torn, the demands of fatherhood and faith pulling me in opposite directions, each urgent in its own way. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out what to do, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
